I will work with anyone to advance the cause of liberty, prosperity, and opportunity in West Michigan. In Congress, I will challenge President-Elect Biden where his policies are at odds with this mission, while being willing to work together where it serves West Michigan. (4/4)

We must also investigate irregularities and process failures, and return signature verification. Allegations that would impact presidential results have not withstood scrutiny in a court of law, but the haphazard election administration in states like New York is troubling. (3/4)

In response, as Republicans we need to roll up our sleeves and fight for the progress of the last four years. We need to keep building towards a strong economy and an end to our endless wars, while fighting for policies that help working Americans. (2/4)

We have seen a lot in this election: record turnout, COVID measures, legal challenges. With legal challenges unsuccessful in court & Electoral College certification, it weighs on me that roughly half our nation (and our district) remains deeply disappointed in this outcome. (1/4)

@OneMIAlliance In re ‚Äòrich guy‚Äô... it‚Äôs rich people (mostly in NY/NJ/CA) who want this tax break preserved, and expanded if they have their way. It baffles me that democratic politicians argue for it, when it literally only benefits their richest donors. Actually, now that I say it out loud... https://t.co/6QW6hwyoz1
@LanceAScott All for better aligning contributions to / benefits from federal gov‚Äôt. SALT deduction doesn‚Äôt do that, and if anything further complicates balancing receipts and outlays.

@SeptemberDresan The deduction means that state/local tax obligation can be deducted from federal tax obligation. Eg, fed gov‚Äôt implicitly subsidizes high-tax cities/states at the expense of low/no-tax cities and states. Not against jurisdictions levying appropriate taxes for services.

Enough w/failed policies. There is no silver-bullet here, but by committing to improving economic and educational opportunities, continuing to encourage investment + criminal justice reform, & rebuilding trust in police we can build a better future for all in West Michigan. (7/7)

We need to support entrepreneurs & improve access to small biz loans. We need to reopen schools so kids don‚Äôt fall further behind and implement reforms to improve outcomes. We need policies that address cyclical poverty + housing insecurity, not perpetuate it. (6/7)

One thing is clear- tho increased killings pre-date COVID/protests, societal disruption & erosion of trust in law enforcement has poured fuel on the fire. First we need to equip and empower police to do their jobs well and rebuild trust btwn police + communities they serve. (5/7)

Revenge is just one negative feedback loop at play. Lack of economic + educational opportunity limits prospects & makes criminal pathways more likely, which in turn discourages urban investment and creation of economic + educational opportunity. We have to break the cycle. (3/7)

These trends pre-date COVID, pre-date George Floyd protests and subsequent undermining of trust in police. I‚Äôve spoken with local law enforcement leaders, and they note that violence often snowballs. First a killing, then revenge, then avenging the revenge. (2/7)

City of Grand Rapids homicides:
-2018: 9 killed
-2019: 17 killed 
-2020: 35 killed* 

(*to date, surpassing previous record of 34 killings in 1993)

Staggering, heartbreaking numbers. Similarly outrageous is how little outrage there is. We must do better. So what to do? (1/7) https://t.co/JvFmMd1BnP
